title: 108_hr1676
content: The "Federal Law Enforcement Officers Pay Equity and Reform Act" limits premium pay for federal law enforcement officers and provides special pay adjustments for officers in certain areas. The Federal Law Enforcement Pay Reform Act of 1990 is amended to change Section 404(b)(1) by updating the language after the semicolon. The metropolitan statistical areas with the highest differentials are Boston-Lawrence-Salem, MA-NH (24.4%), Chicago-Gary-Lake County, IL-IN-WI (24.5%), Los Angeles-Anaheim-Riverside, CA (27.1%), New York-Northern New Jersey-Long Island, NY-NJ-CT (26.1%), and Sacramento-Yolo, CA (21%). The amendment made by this section applies to pay for service in pay periods starting on or after the enactment date of this Act in various metropolitan statistical areas, including San Francisco-Oakland-San Jose, CA (32.03%), San Diego, CA (27.1%), Seattle-Tacoma-Bremerton, WA (27.5%), and Washington-Baltimore, DC-MD-VA-WV (24.3%). SEC. 4. Separate pay, evaluation, and promotion system for federal law enforcement officers. The Office of Personnel Management will conduct a study and submit a report to Congress on the need for a separate pay, evaluation, and promotion system for Federal law enforcement officers. If deemed appropriate, a demonstration project may be implemented within 12 months. The Office of Personnel Management will implement a demonstration project within 12 months to determine if a separate system for Federal law enforcement officers would improve personnel management. The project will follow provisions of title 5, United States Code, and a report will be submitted to Congress before the project's termination date. The Office of Personnel Management will evaluate a system tested under a demonstration project for Federal law enforcement officers and make recommendations to Congress. The term "Federal law enforcement officer" includes officers defined by specific sections of title 5, United States Code, and those serving in or under the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
